reasoning: Alex claims to be bedridden with a fever, but evidence (posting from a beach resort the same day) strongly suggests they’re not sick and are deceiving their boss to justify taking the day off.

“My dog ate it” is a stereotypical excuse for missing homework and the add-on “I swear it really happened this time” implies the student has used it before and expects disbelief, suggesting it’s likely an invented excuse rather than a factual claim.

The car has visible rust, which strongly suggests it hasn’t been consistently protected from the elements; claiming it was “garage-kept its whole life” is likely a deceptive sales pitch rather than a true, literal description.
In heavy rain without an umbrella, calling it a “PERFECT day for a walk” likely expresses frustration by saying the opposite of what is meant.
The coworker is very late to an important meeting, so “So nice of you to join us” is likely meant as a pointed, critical remark rather than genuine appreciation.
In the context of completely burning dinner, “you’ve really outdone yourself” is used to mock/criticize rather than sincerely praise, signaling sarcastic intent.
A fire station can’t literally “save itself” like a person; the phrasing highlights the ironic situation that a place meant to fight fires burned down.

A grammar teacher writing “Your” instead of “You’re” is a notable mistake; the post is likely intentionally ironic (or self-deprecating) to highlight the grammar issue, implying the person’s error motivated them to teach grammar.

A health food blogger calling fast food “real food” clashes with their usual persona/values, so the caption likely uses ironic humor to acknowledge the inconsistency rather than literally claiming fast food is the only “real” food.

In context you believe the haircut looks bad, but you say something positive to protect your friend’s feelings and match their pride. It’s not sarcasm (no clear cues of mockery), but a polite, prosocial falsehood.
They say it’s “delicious” even though no one likes it, likely to spare Grandma’s feelings and be polite rather than to mock her.

Parents often use exaggerated praise to encourage a child. “Best drawing I’ve ever seen” is likely not strictly true literally, but is meant as supportive encouragement rather than deception for gain or sarcasm.
This is a straightforward weather forecast phrased as a factual prediction, with no cues of sarcasm, irony, or deception.
In a restaurant ordering context, “I’ll have the chicken salad, please” is a direct, conventional way to state what the customer wants to order, with no cues of sarcasm, irony, or deception.
In a doctor’s office, saying “Your test results came back normal” is typically a straightforward medical update with no cue of sarcasm or deception.
